Posts.Title: Bring a smile, or share a laugh Fitztwins china

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2009 06:17AM - edited Nov 19, 2009 12:46AM by Duffymom I heard a conversation from the new tv show "Modern Family".  Wife says to husband "I love you!".  Husband doesn't respond.  Wife says "aren't you going to tell me you love me too?".  Husband replies "I told you at our wedding that I loved you.  If anything changes, I'll let you know!" This is something my husband might say!  I think it's pretty funny.  I've started watching the show and catching up on past episodes online.  Also very funny favorite show is "Big Bang Theory". I laughted out loud during last night's episode. Kathy

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2009 07:15PM Duffymom wrote: I was on Gemzar/Carbo/Avastin from Dec. to Sept. with very good results.  Unfortunately I've developed an allergic reaction to the Carbo.  I guess that's typical after about 8 treatments.  Beginning Oct I am on Gemzar/Avastin only.  I have a scan in Dec to see if that's enough. I too have the platelet issue with platelets.  Because of that I have chemo every 4 weeks.  Very few SE from these drugs.  A good combo to be on.  Best wishes! Kathy
Posts.Title: stage 1v cmfr1 Duffymom

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2009 01:48PM Duffymom wrote: Great news Elaine!  My latest PET scan in Sept also showed I'm stable on the monthly chemo I am having.  I always think that I can relax for awhile until my next scan.  I'm sure you do this too.  I hope that the meds you get will help with your nerve pain.  I've heard great things about PARP inhibitors, especially for triple negs like me.  Unfortunately I'll probably have to wait for clinical trials to be done before I can try it.  But so far what I'm doing is working.  I hope you continue to receive good news!  Stable is a great word! Kathy

Posts.Title: New here virginiamom Mazy1959

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2010 11:16PM Duffymom wrote: Zeeka - ditto everything you said.  I hate the first moment when I wake up in the morning and realize - oh yeah! I have cancer!.  I am a huge planner and it sucks to not be able to make plans. Always express how you feel.  For me it's therapy and those who don't like my honesty can either not read it or listen to it.  It's tough to be told "months" to live and I know that could mean a lot of different things.  I choose to make it a lot of them and am trying to be as positive as possible. I'm also being realistic and have some projects that I can't put off any more. Hugs - Kathy
Posts.Title: not knowing zeeka71 kenzie57

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2010 03:13PM Duffymom wrote: I was on Gemzar from last Dec. to November.  It was the easiest chemo I've ever been on.  Low platelets were my biggest issue with needing to go to chemo every 4 weeks in order to give my body time to recover.  My last PET scan in Dec shows cancer is stable for most of my body, however an mri the next day showed cancer has gotten into my spinal fluid and it's now in my brain. For now dr is suspending Gemzar until she hits my brain then she's switching me to Xeloda. Glad to hear positive things about Xeloda and some of the doses people have been on. Didn't lose hair, it did thin a bit but no one else notices.  Good luck mom! It's a good chemo to be on. Kathy
Posts.Title: Gemzar shopper16 Nanalinda

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2009 05:46PM Duffymom wrote: Thanks you ladies for sharing your treatment stories with me.  Keep updating me.  I want to go into this as prepared as I can.  1 week until my PET scan and 2 weeks until new treatment.  Lynn I am encouraged by your continuing to work.  I started back at pre-school yesterday and love it!  It's MWF all day so I have T & Th to recover in between.  I hope you all feel better soon and that this treatment works so well it will be worth all the side effects. Kathy
Posts.Title: Anyone on Ixempra - esp. TN? Duffymom kenzie57

Posts.Content: Duffymom wrote: Just finished 11 rounds of Gemzar/Carbo but have to stop due to new allergic reaction.  Dr. said Ixempra will be next.  From what I've read on-line it's often given with Xeloda. Not sure what I'll get. PET scan 9-8 with dr appt & treatment 9-15. Just trying to prepare myself. I have had no side effects from the Gemzar/Carbo, except platelets rebounding slowly.  I've even kept most of my hair. It makes me nervous to switch to something else. Reocurrance 10/08 of bone mets, chest wall, lymph nodes.  Appreciate hearing from anyone taking this relatively new drug.  I posted on the Triple Neg forum with no response.  thanks - Kathy Dx 10/2008, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/12 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Anyone on Ixempra - esp. TN? Duffymom kenzie57

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2009 09:24PM Duffymom wrote: I too, read this thread on a regular basis, but have never written.  As a fellow triple neg, I am so angry at how quickly this disease can come on and progress.  Thank you to everyone for the updates. I get tears in my eyes every time I read the responses.  Wishing Heidi, and all the other lovely ladies (& little bro), peace and comfort. Kathy

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2009 11:29PM Duffymom wrote: Denise,  So sorry about your scan news.  I like that you say you aren't ready to give up - don't!  Can I ask about your Ixempra experience?  I get one more try with Gemzar/Carbo trying to alleviate another allergic reaction and if it doesn't work, I go on Ixempra.  It makes me nervous as the Gemzar/Carbo has kept me stable for several months and I have little SE.  Keep us updated with what the dr/neurosurgeon says. Prayers and strength for you! - Kathy

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2009 06:46PM Duffymom wrote: Keep posting on how Ixempra is going for you.  I've been on Gemzar since last Dec. and when it stops working my next choice is either Ixempra or Xeloda.  I'm trying to read all postings about both so when it's time to change I am somewhat knowledgeable.  I am triple neg and my onc says Ixempra is supposed to be the "new" treatment.  Wishing you the best. Kathy

Posts.Title: Anyone on Ixempra - esp. TN? Duffymom kenzie57

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2009 10:15PM Duffymom wrote: Scans are a good thing, bad thing.  We want them to reassure us that the pains we're feeling are not cancer taking over our bodies.  If we hear good news we can kind of relax until the next scan.  But we don't want to have them if the news is bad.  I'm happy that you don't have to wait long to get your results.  I have most of my scans on a Thursday and a dr. appt the next Tues.  The waiting is hard.   You are NOT crazy.  Thinking positive thoughts for you.  Kathy
Posts.Title: Why is it.... DianaT lukejessesmom

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2009 04:32AM Duffymom wrote: I had the same issue when 1st found out cancer moved into my bones.  Lots of pain in back shoulder blade but scans didn't show anything there.  Happy to say that almost 1 year later I don't have that pain anymore.  I've had 4 rounds of Taxol both with 1st diagnosis and after reoccurance when I was having 15 rads to my spine.  I didn't lose my hair but it thinned quite a bit.  Biggest problem has been neuropathy with feet - pain after walking but I've learned to deal with it.   I'm currently on Gemzar/Avastin.  I hope Taxol works for you and you don't have any major SE.  Kathy
Posts.Title: PET/CT scan results in. Time for a wig! donnabee RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2009 10:45PM Duffymom wrote: I am keeping watch. I am part of Heidi's vigil. "Life is a series of unpredictable events. You gotta to through them; you can't go around them."  May your journey be peaceful and painfree. Kathy
Posts.Title: Heidi Update-it isn't pretty Heidi_Ho zeeka71

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2009 11:04PM Duffymom wrote: Thank you ladies for your input.  It's hard for me to think about this because right now I feel more like a "normal" person than a cancer person.  I'm a pre-school teacher 3 days a week and start back the week before I have chemo.  In 3 years I've only missed 1 day of work.  It's such a rewarding and normal thing to do that I'm scared about Ixempra's side effects not allowing me to continue.  Maybe because I do feel so well and strong, the side effects won't be as bad? (wishful thinking :) Thank you all for your support.

Posts.Title: Janis / Fitztwins, when is your scan? MJLToday mthomp2020

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2009 12:11AM Duffymom wrote: Hi Marsha!  Elizabeth is right.  Gemzar is a "Gem" as far as chemos go.  I have very few SE with the exception of my platelets not rebounding quickly.  Most of the time I'm having chemo every 4 weeks although in Sept I had to go 5 weeks due to low platelets.  I get a Neulasta shot the day after chemo, but always have no matter what chemo I'm on.  I've had Gemzar since December.  I hope I can stay on it a long time.  The "Anyone on Gemzar" thread will give you tons of info. I hope Gemzar treats you well! Kathy
Posts.Title: Gemzar Marsha56 Duffymom

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2009 11:03PM - edited Oct 21, 2009 11:05PM by Duffymom Tonto - I am so happy you took the time to talk.  For me talking about my cancer in a form of therapy.  I have a Caringbridge site that I journal in periodically.  I'm also very open with my friends.  I used to come to these boards, then took a break and the last few months it has become part of my daily routine.  I'm amazed at the friendships people have developed through these forums and feel a little jealous.  It is comforting to come to a place where people truly understand what you are going through.  Thanks for the info on Xeloda.  That is next in line for me if/when my current treatment stops working. Sorry you had to join this club, none of us like being here. Kathy

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 11:54PM Duffymom wrote: Even though we all new this was coming, it is so hard to read.  Prayers and special hugs to her family. Another TN gone :(
Posts.Title: Stephanie is an Angel 2timer Britt

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2009 04:12PM Duffymom wrote: I agree that working is a good thing if chemo allows it.  I work 3 days a week as a pre-school teacher.  I had a difficult time over the summer break as my days had no purpose.  Now that I'm back, doing something "normal" I feel better about myself.  Even though I come home exhausted sometimes, it's worth it.  I'm glad I have Tue and Thurs off to recupperate. When I was 1st diagnosed stage IV everyone did treat me differently, esp my husband.  He's never been a romantic, more sarcasm. Then he'd look at me with puppy dog eyes and treating me differently.  As time has gone on, and things are going ok, things are more back to normal. But I've been stage IV for a year now so everyone has gotten used to it.  My kids don't even ask me how chemo went anymore!  I've learned that some friends can't take any bad news and I have 1 good friend that I can say anything to and she won't freak out or try to talk me out of what I'm saying - that's important. I look forward to reading more of your posts - I'm enjoying them! Kathy

Posts.Title: A message from River's husband Fitztwins lizws

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2009 11:42PM Duffymom wrote: I had a PET scan that shows things are "stable". I've been on Gemzar/Carbo. Had a bad allergic reaction and dr was going to switch me to Ixempra.  We're both frustrated by that since it's been working to keep the cancer from progressing and I have minimal SE.  After reading many posts on this site, I convinced her to let me try one more time getting add'l steroids, benadryl and running the infusion as slow as they can - going from 3 hr treatment to 6 hr.  I was supposed to do this yesterday but platelet count said "no go" so I'll try again next week.  I'm hoping this will work, but if it doesn't I'll have to switch in Oct.  I'm having a liver MRI tomorrow (thurs) because all my scans have shown "inhomogenous" appearance of my liver and she wants to get more info about it. My markers have been hovering around 59.  Back to working 3 days a week (preschool teacher).  It's a great distraction and makes part of my life feel "normal".  Also taking advantage of feeling good by going to the beach mid Oct.  Hugs to all you lovely ladies! - Kathy
